Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A monthly food drive for the local homeless shelter is scheduled to take place at the convent today.
Story:
The phone pressed against my ear, I listened as Mr. Jenkins, a long-time customer, unleashed his frustration. “How do I know this isn’t a scam? I want every detail, right now!” His voice trembled with suspicion, and I could almost see his furrowed brow through the line. As a telemarketer, I was trained to remain calm, answer every objection, and never let a call end unresolved. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “Don’t lose a customer, no matter what.”

But as I glanced at the clock, my heart tightened. The convent’s monthly food drive was starting in minutes. The sisters would be gathering in the kitchen, sorting cans and preparing meals for the homeless. As a nun, I was expected to be there, hands busy, heart open, serving those in need. Sister Agnes had reminded me just this morning, “Your presence matters, dear. The community counts on you.”

I felt torn, the headset heavy on my head, the habit warm on my shoulders. Mr. Jenkins waited for answers, my sisters waited for me. My mind raced, caught between duty to my job and my calling to serve.
